questions.text: Identify the condition of the given Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratosis obturans The above image is an otoscopic picture/ endoscopic picture showing a hard wax/ white wax in the bony part of external auditory canal pointing towards KERATOSIS OBTURANS.

Highyeild:

Collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus is called keratosis obturans. Pathology: Usually the epithelium from 'surface of tympanic membrane migrates onto the posterior meatal wall. If there is failure of this migration or any kind of obstruction to migration caused by wax results in accumulation of the epithelial plug in the deep meatus. Clinical Features Usually patient presents with ear pain, hearing loss, ear discharge or tinnitus. Signs On examination the ear canal is filled with a pearly white mass of keratin material. Removal of this mass may result in widening of bony meatus with ulceration and granuloma. Treatment Removal of keratotic mass by syringing or instrumentation. Treatment. Keratotic mass is removed either by syringing or instrumentation.

questions.text: A child with H/o severe pain in throat with hoarseness of voice, with high grade fever with toxic looks & presenting with clinical condition as shown in the image. Identify the lesion:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diphtheria Above image shows pseudomembrane which is characteristically seen in Diptheria.

Highyeild:

Diphtheria is an infection caused by the bacterium Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Sign and symptoms may vary from mild to severe. They usually start two to six days after exposure. Symptoms often come on fairly gradually, beginning with a sore throat and fever. In severe cases, a grey or white patch develops in the throat. This can block the airway and create a barking cough as in croup. The neck may swell in part due to enlarged lymph nodes. Sign & Symptoms The symptoms of diphtheria usually begin two to seven days after infection. Symptoms of diphtheria include fever of 38 °C (100.4 °F) or above, chills, fatigue, bluish skin coloration (cyanosis), sore throat, hoarseness, cough, headache, difficulty swallowing, painful swallowing, difficulty breathing, rapid breathing, foul-smelling and blood stained nasal discharge, and lymphadenopathy. Children most commonly affected. Oropharynx commonly involved. Larynx and Nasal cavity can be affected. In the oropharynx, a greyish white membrane forms over tonsil and spreads to soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. It is quite tenacious and causes bleeding when removed. Cervical lymph nodes involvement giving bull neck. Patient ill, toxemic, fever seldom rise above 38°c Complications Exotoxin toxic to heart and nerves can cause myocarditis, cardiac arrhythmia and acute circulatory failure. Neurological involvement includes paralysis of soft palate, diaphragm, and ocular muscles

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Acute membranous tonsillitis. It is a stage ahead of acute follicular tonsillitis when exudation from the crypts coalesces to form a membrane on the surface of tonsil. OPTION B- In follicular tonsillitis Infection spreads into the crypts which become filled with purulent material, presenting at the openings of crypts as yellowish spots. OPTION D- Aphthous ulcer may involve any part of oral cavity or oropharynx. Sometimes, it is solitary and may involve the tonsil and pillars. It may be small or quite large and alarming. It is very painful.

Extraedge:

Treatment Dose of anti-toxin < 48 hr or if membrane limited: 20,000 to 40,000 units >48 hr or extensive membrane: 80k to 120k Antibiotic: benzyl penicillin or erythromycin

questions.text: Name the manoeuvre shown in the Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epley Given image is of epley’s maneuver. (Epley Repositioning Maneuver for BPPV )

Highyeild:

BPPV - benign paroxysmal positional vertigo It is a manoeuvre done to reposition the otoconal debris from the posterior semicircular canal back into the utricle, seen in BPPV. BPPV mostly involves posterior semicircular canal, can also be associated with history of head trauma and ear infection. The vertigo is fatiguable on assuming the same position but can be induced again after period of rest. The manoeuvre consists of five positions (Figure above): Position 1. With the head turned 45°, the patient is made to lie down in head-hanging position (Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre). It will cause vertigo and nystagmus. Wait till vertigo and nystagmus subside. Position 2. Head is now turned so that affected ear is facing up at a 90° rotation. Position 3. The whole body and head are now rotated away from the affected ear to a lateral recumbent position in a 90°-rotation face-down position. Position 4. Patient is now brought to a sitting position with head still turned to the unaffected side by 45°. Position 5. The head is now turned forward and chin brought down 20°.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following picture of Tympanic Membrane. Most Probable diagnosis (marked with arrow):
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tubercular Otitis Media In the above image multiple perforations are seen in pars tensa of tympanic membrane which is classically seen in Tubercular otitis media.

Highyeild:

Tubercular otitis media is characterized by following features Painless otorrhea Multiple perforations Foul smelling watery ear discharge Pale granulations Severe hearing loss, out of proportion to symptoms, mostly conductive Facial paralysis can be associated

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B- Syphilitic otitis media is a rare condition. Spirochaetes reach middle ear through eustachian tube when syphilitic lesions are present in the nose or nasopharynx. Infection may also be blood-borne. Sensory end organs of the inner ear and their nerves are soon invaded by spirochaetes leading to profound sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus and vertigo. OPTION C- Necrotizing otitis externa, also called malignant otitis externa, is caused by pseudomonas infection in an elderly patient with diabetes. OPTION D- Fungal otitis media is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Supraglottic Generally, an inspiratory stridor suggests airway obstruction above the glottis (supraglottis or pharynx) E.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

Highyeild:

While an expiratory stridor is indicative of obstruction in the lower trachea (thoracic trachea, primary or secondary bronchi) e.g. Bronchial foreign body and tracheal stenosis.

Extraedge:

A biphasic stridor suggests a lesion of glottic or subglottic lesion and cervical trachea E.g. laryngeal papilloma, vocal cord paralysis and subglottis stenosis.

questions.text: The most common site of the branchial cyst is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid Most common site of branchial cyst is anterior border of sternocleidomastoid.

Highyeild:

Branchial Cleft Cyst in The Neck Branchial cyst It is common in second decade of life. Cyst presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck, anterior to SCM muscle. Mass is smooth, round, fluctuant, non tender and non trans illuminant. A painful increase in size at the time of upper respiratory infection can occur. Anomalies of second branchial arch are the most common. May be associated with sinus. Treatment of branchial cyst is surgical excision along with its tract, if present

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the Image given below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laryngeal Papilloma The above image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

Highyeild:

Papillomas are benign epithelial tumors that are caused by infection with the human papilloma virus ( HPV ). They are the most common benign neoplasms affecting the larynx and upper respiratory Tract. Juvenile papilloma Recurrent respiratory laryngeal papillomatosis Common in anterior part of glottis, esp. anterior commissure. HPV 6 and 11 Associated with maternal genital warts. Intrauterine transmission Presentation: Hoarseness, Abnormal cry, Dyspnea, Stridor. Remission common: M alignant Change Uncommon. Treatment: CO 2 laser, Intralesional cidofovir Adult onset Single, Less Aggressive, Small, Non Recurrent, Same location, same management.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Under the epithelium of vocal cords is a potential space with scanty subepithelial connective tissues. It is bounded above and below by the arcuate lines, in front by anterior commissure, and behind by vocal process of arytenoid. Oedema of this space causes fusiform swelling of the membranous cords (Reinke’s oedema). OPTION C- In laryngeal malignancy B symptoms will also be present. OPTION D- Tracheomalacia is a structural abnormality of the tracheal cartilage allowing collapse of its walls and airway obstruction.
